❓How is Monkeypox spread?

Unlike Covid, monkeypox can not spread easily through a population as it requires very close contact. 

Routes of transmission from one person to another are via large exhaled droplets and skin-to-skin contact with open sores

❓What are the symptoms?

The UKHSA says the initial symptoms include:
❌Fever
❌Headache
❌Muscle aches
❌Backache
❌Swollen lymph nodes
❌Chills 
❌Exhaustion

❓What is the Monkeypox virus?

The name monkeypox is somewhat misleading as it is a virus that circulates most often in small mammals in Africa, such as rats

🐍 While real reptiles navigate using their eyes and smell, engineers at the UK Atomic Energy Authority have developed an ultrasound system to tell what the snake is  feeling
But instead of spitting venom, the heads of the multi-million pound serpents have been fitted with a bespoke laser system capable of melting, welding and treating steel in seconds

➡️ For almost a decade, British experts have been building a mechanical device which will slide around inside the walls of the future nuclear reactors like a metal-clad basilisk doing essential repairs and maintenance
☢️ However, inside these reactors is a hot and radioactive environment which would kill a person, so any maintenance must be done by machines...

Nuclear fusion is seen by many as a panacea for the world’s energy crisis, as well as climate change, because it produces a huge amount of energy from a small amount of fuel and makes no greenhouse gas emissions

⚡️ Slithering steel serpents are being developed to carry out maintenance works inside reactors that could power up the country...

Could robotic snakes keep Britain’s nuclear fusion hopes alive?

In her case, she knew she was pretty good’ mainly because she thrashed the boys. 

🗣️It’s pretty rare for a girl to beat a boy in tennis, but I was doing it here and there. I never considered it as a full-time career until recently, though.’

As a child in Bromley, Raducanu would do anything as long as it could involve winning. 

🎒I think they wanted to give me all sorts of skills, and also it was like childcare, because they were working, so I was thrown into every extracurricular school activity they had on’

My parents’ culture has definitely played a big part in my mindset, because I’ve always been taught the way they think. says Raducanu 

They’re really tough to please, so I’ve always had to work extra hard and have high standards

🌎All the on-court disappointments this season have forced Raducanu to be philosophical about life on tour, living in hotels all over the world.

It’s tough, I haven’t really got going, but I don’t really mind because I know it’s not always going to be smooth,’ she says.

🏆Plus Emma is also the new champion on the block, which makes beating her a coveted prize.

Yeah, but I don’t mind, it comes with it,’ she says. 

I take it as a compliment. I’ll improve faster, at the end of the day, because I’m having to bring this high level every time’

🇺🇸The months since her US Open win haven’t been straightforward.

In April, she split with Torben Beltz, her third coach in a year, leaving her as a self-described loner’

Then she dealt with small injuries including back and hip problems, plus persistent blisters

I’d say I’m really normal, my mum shouts at me for everything. Like,  Wash your face!  Because otherwise I pretty much don’t. I’m just a normal kid, a normal 19-year-old,’ Raducanu says. 

🗣️She says she is at home two or three days a month, if that

My bedroom is a mess

✍️ I think that she would have felt compassion, above all else, towards the leading ladies in the  Wagatha Christie  drama,  writes Laura Thompson. 

Read the full story 👇

It took hysterical possession of the newspapers, and led to questions in the House as to the cost of the police operation

For years Christie carried the visible taint of the story – indeed, she never quite recovered from her assault by the 1920s equivalent of a Twitter mob

In December 1926 she  disappeared  for 11 days, almost certainly in a misjudged strategy for reclaiming the husband who wanted to leave her. 

When she was found alive and well in a hotel, after a nationwide search, her private mental anguish became the most public of scandals

🗞️Agatha Christie’s understanding of the press derived, in part, from her first-hand experience of its excesses. 

Here, perhaps, is the strongest connection of all. 

Almost a century ago, Christie was in the eye of a tabloid storm as fierce as the one that now bears her name

📖Coleen Rooney’s scheme to identify, by a process of elimination, the author of the anonymous leaks is somewhat reminiscent of Christie’s 1943 novel, The Moving Finger.

The novel centres upon similar attempts to trace the source of a series of scurrilous anonymous letters

📚As for the  plot  aspect of the Wagatha saga – this, too, would surely have appealed. 

There is even a vital missing clue, the phone belonging to Rebekah Vardy’s agent – also in the frame as a source of newspaper stories – which now lies somewhere in the North Sea

💷Christie herself grew up with little money, her amiable gentlemanly father having squandered most of it. 

She understood, always, the urgent need to acquire security – understood, too, that there are many ways of earning it

She would certainly have  got  Coleen Rooney, the bright daughter of a Liverpool bricklayer who now lives in a £4 million mansion.

Her books feature feisty girls full of wit, such as the heroine of The Sittaford Mystery who stops at nothing to save her boyfriend from the gallows

📱Of course Christie would have loathed the contemporary trappings of this case, especially the ugly idiocies of social media (she never even enjoyed television).

Yet she moved with the times far more than is generally realised

🔎 Christie was a student of human nature, of motivation, and in essence that is what the Rooney-Vardy showdown is all about.

Two women, watched with who knows what feelings by their husbands, locking balayaged ponytails and refusing to back down

🗨️ One of her last known remarks, before her death in January 1976, was:  I wonder what has happened to Lord Lucan?  

Like most of us, she was fascinated by these real-life stories – not least because her job required her to be

➡️However, that pervasive view of Christie does not quite square with the reality. 

The real Agatha Christie – although a product of the upper-middle class into which she was born in 1890 – was, in truth, a supremely unshockable cosmopolitan

The ongoing trial represents, one would think, an improbable culture clash with the genteel figure of Agatha Christie, whose tea-at-the-vicarage social landscape is one in which chipolatas are merely party sausages, and leaks are found only in drains

🔎The  Wagatha  epithet was conjured on Twitter (where else?)

It was created in tribute to the deductive powers of Mrs Rooney, who – by deliberate deployment of fake stories on her Instagram  – alighted upon Mrs Vardy, who denies the accusation, as the source of tabloid leaks

🕵️‍♀️The  Wagatha Christie  portmanteau is a headline, a hashtag, a phrase with a crazed life of its own. 

❓But what would Dame Agatha Christie have thought of the court battle between Rebekah Vardy and Coleen Rooney?

⚡️Dolphins are self-medicating with coral clinics to treat skin infections
Read the full report here 👇👇

🔎The science of self-medicating animals is known as zoopharmacognosy.

 Many researchers believe humans could discover new medications by studying which plants are selected
🧼🫧 It’s almost like they are showering, cleaning themselves before they go to sleep or get up for the day

🗣️ I hadn’t seen this coral rubbing behaviour described before, and it was clear that the dolphins knew exactly which coral they wanted to use,  said co-lead author Angela Ziltener of the University of Zurich

🪸After years of studying the behaviour, the team realised that the dolphins were agitating the tiny marine invertebrates that make up the coral community.

This caused the coral to release medicated mucus
🌊The strange phenomenon was first observed 13 years ago by biologists from the University of Zurich in the Red Sea off the Egyptian coast...

🐬Dolphins are using coral clinics’ to treat skin infections.

⚡️ I went to report in Ukraine - and came back with a dog

Do you want to come to London with me? I whispered to her. 

🐶 She started licking my cheek again and I knew in that moment that was it. I was bringing her home 

Read the full story👇

💬 A local called Vladimir, who was surveying the damage to his home when we found him, explained that she had turned up on Day 1 of the invasion.

 And although he had been feeding her, he had no idea where she came from

We also had a lot of work to do and having an animal cutting around with us would be a logistical nightmare. 

 Yet, there was something about this little girl that stopped me thinking logically and setting her back down among the rubble felt out of the question

💬 I knew trying to take her home was reckless,  says Danielle.

 We had not long been in Ukraine and I had decided to leave the place I was renting back in the UK, so I didn’t even have a home of my own to go back to
🐕 The way she responded to me, which was to lick me all over my face and bury her head into my chest made me feel like she had been deprived of this attention
He called me over to look at her and I immediately scooped her up from the rubble and hugged her tight to my chest,  Danielle writes

✍️ Paul and I had entered a blown-up house when he felt a scratching at his leg...

❓The question today is whether the belated adoption of such techniques changes will allow Brexit Britain better to secure its food supplies.

🗣️ It allows us, for the first time, to make small precise changes in a plant’s existing DNA that mimic changes that could occur naturally,  says Professor Wendy Harwood, head of the Crop Transformation Group at the John Innes Centre

🗨️ Gene-editing removes DNA, genetic modification adds it,  says Prof Napier.

That difference, scientists think, should make a significant difference in winning public acceptance this time around.

Gene editing, unlike modification, is the harnessing of a  natural process

🗣️ When they are surveyed, people express all sorts of preferences about organic or GM food,  says Prof Napier.

 For the majority, those preferences become secondary to rising prices during a global food shock like the one we have now as a consequence of the conflict in Ukraine

🐜 Above all, farmers will be able to plant crops resistant to disease and insects, driving higher yields and greater efficiencies that could lower costs – at a time when war, pestilence and drought are causing food prices to rocket

Stopping the spread of disease can also come down to genetics, says Professor Johnathan Napier at Rothamsted Research.

 Most pathogens latch on to a plant by recognising a host protein. If you edit out that recognition factor you effectively make the pathogen blind to the crop.

🔴 As well as tackling the food crisis, gene-editing crops could lead to a whole range of convenient foods – salad leaves rich in nutrients, cherries without stones, or coffee that is naturally decaffeinated, for example

🗣️  This is an incredibly important issue,  says Murray Grant, professor of food security at the University of Warwick. 

 Fertiliser prices have quadrupled. Wheat prices are predicted to double this year. Its one of those perfect storms

🗨️Last week Sara Menker, the CEO of agriculture analytics firm Gro Intelligence, told the United Nations that wheat stocks around the world were running dangerously low. 

 We currently only have 10 weeks of global consumption sitting in inventory around the world,  she said

➡️No longer - the Government is introducing legislation relaxing the restrictions on the sowing of gene-edited crops.

Sources have told The Daily Telegraph that they will help protect Britain from the growing threat to food security posed by climate change and the war in Ukraine

🗣️ Our scientists were among the first to develop gene editing in plants,  said Professor Sophien Kamoun, group leader at The Sainsbury Laboratory in Norwich.

 Yet, we had to sit back and watch other countries, like the US and Japan, bring their bio-edited plants to market

🔴 A few years ago, researchers at the University of Cambridge developed a precision gene-editing technique known as Crispr.

But then they faced their own problem – unlike large parts of the world, Britain and the EU were adamantly opposed to such techniques

➡️ There is another way.

By snipping out 48 nucleotides – the basic building blocks of DNA – it is possible to create a tomato that is more resistant to mildew

This makes tomatoes cheaper to produce and, because they need to be sprayed less, better for the environment

🍅You might not think that we produce many tomatoes in Britain, but we do: about 100,000 tons, a fifth of our annual consumption.

Yet British tomato farmers face a problem: powdery mildew, a disease against which their principal defence has long been fungicide

❓Can gene-edited crops solve the world’s food crisis?

Ukrainian forces have been resupplying their front lines as fast as possible, even delivering stocks of NLAW by civilian vehicles

NLAWs can effectively engage targets up to 800m. 

⚡️ The weapons are also designed to be ultra versatile - The theory is they can be fired from enclosed spaces in urban environments, but are also ideal for rural guerrilla warfare due to their mobility

How do NLAWs work?

The lightweight guided missile can be unslung, unfolded and fired in as little as 15 seconds.

​​🎯 They are fired at 440mph using their own navigation and guidance system to predict where the target will be on impact
🗣️  Give us more toys like these and there will be more destroyed tanks,  says another, saying he would like to put a Belfast-built anti-tank weapon into the hands of every civilian

⚡ Inside the Wagner Group: Death is our business – and business is good’

🔴 Three weeks ago, Ukrainian intelligence told journalists that President Zelensky had survived three assassination attempts, two by Wagner soldiers.

Again, this week, we heard that there had been another attempt on his life by the Wagner Group

🔴 Wagner has a bloody reputation, earned in places like Syria, Libya and the Central African Republic.

🔴 In Syria, Wagner mercenaries were filmed beating a Syrian army deserter with a sledgehammer, then cutting off his hands and head with the blade of a shovel

❓ The Kremlin certainly has a long history of dezinformatsiya and provokatsiya, lies told to confuse and demoralise the enemy.

🔴 A gang of several hundred super-assassins being secretly airlifted into Ukraine does sound like something dreamt up by a propagandist in the Kremlin.

⚡️ Is your job at risk of becoming extinct? - How machines could take over our workplaces
📸Ukrainian servicemen stand in trenches at a position north of Kyiv

Will your job exist in the future?

Read the full analysis here to find out 👇

Badminton explains:  AI will not be good at creative problem solving, empathetic reasoning, philosophical debate and the human group dynamics of collaborating for a very long time .

🧠  Deep human connection, empathy, curiosity will be vital. Human inquiry will steer the ship.

But amid all the disappearing jobs there is good news... 

 While there will be a shift towards automation, we will be freed from repetitive work to do more creative things together. 

🌍  I call this new world the wisdom economy’

🤖 AI has proved to be more effective than human doctors in terms of diagnosing certain conditions.

Similar advances are being made in dentistry, where robots are already doing routine jobs better than humans can do them

While accountancy, construction, law and medicine will still exist, they will look very different. 

🏥  For example, right now we are in the early stages of fully-automated surgery – that’s the trajectory we are heading towards

❌ What jobs will become extinct?

Taxi drivers are likely to be replaced by self-driving cars; cashiers and retail staff will largely be replaced by machines that will let you pay for items yourself.

Deliveries will be done by drones...

All human jobs will be automated within the next 120 years.

📅  Machines are predicted to be better than us at translating languages by 2024; working in retail by 2031; writing a bestselling book by 2049; and performing surgery by 2053,  claims Badminton

❓What lies ahead for children being born today? Will robots be doing our work?

 It’s not which jobs will be automated, but when they will be automated: every part of the economy will be affected,  says Nikolas Badminton author of Facing Our Futures

💸 The jobs that will pay the highest salaries in 2040

Most of the professions we do today will be obsolete in two decades, so how can you guide your children to a successful career? ⬇️

Keira Knightley: Its impossible to be liked by everyone
Read the full interview 👇

Where does she wants to go next?

✍️I would like to write,’ she says. 

At the moment, my brain feels so frazzled with small children, but I would really like to see what I could do.

Keira is both wildly excited and utterly terrified about returning to work for her latest film.

I want to do it, but I’ve been a full-time mum for the last 19 months. I haven’t left the little one. She doesn’t know life without me putting her down for a nap.

Motherhood, on a personal level, informs all of Keira’s film choices. 

Family comes first, and if the logistics don’t allow them to be with her, then it’s just not going to work.

📺 I had to pull out of a TV series that I really wanted to do last year,’ she says

You cannot please everybody, and yet women are still held up in order to do exactly that – that is impossible’ says Keira

We objectify young women, whether they’ve made a decision to commodify themselves or not, and that makes me very angry.’

There is a fury in me,’ she says, of the mental scars she still carries. 

I’m furious that that is the position that we put young women in and, as the mother of two daughters, I’m furious for their sake

She was barely out of her teens at the time.

➡️ By 22, the intensity of that experience for Keira led to a breakdown and, after extensive therapy, a PTSD diagnosis

Keira tells @telegraphstella about the scrutiny that films such as Pirates of the Caribbean had put her under. 

📸Paparazzi arrived on her doorstep one morning in 2003 and didn’t leave her alone for five years, screaming abuse at her every time she opened her front door

🗣️I’m not frightened of contentious,’ Keira says

It’s impossible that you’re going to be liked by everybody. That’s just a task you’re never going to win, but I love doing work that people will have a dialogue with, whether that’s positive or negative’

There is a fury in me 

⭐️ Keira Knightley speaks to @telegraphstella about like-ability, motherhood and feminism

Thinking back to when their own children were non-verbal, they weren’t eating solid food, she says she often wondered,  How are our lives going to get better?’

McGuinness adds:  When you’re in it, it’s hard to see your way through, but it does get easier.
While Christine is emphatic that she doesn’t define autism or what an autistic person is like,  and neither do our children , the past year has taught them a lot about themselves and their family

In the past, Christine admits she had blamed herself:

🗣️ When they weren’t speaking, socialising and weren’t eating food, I instantly blamed myself.  But now I know there’s nothing we could have done differently. Our children were born autistic and so was I.

It’s a revelation that still rocks McGuinness.  It’s my family, and I had no idea. And now I see it all the time.

 What I couldn’t believe is that my own daughter who I love to bits has been doing it with me. When it got explained to me, I thought How have I not noticed this?’

That Christine appears so calm and collected is something they learnt is typical of women with autism. 

Girls often exhibit behaviour that mimics what they see around them, in an attempt to fit in and go unnoticed. This is known as masking.

It was by taking part in the documentary that the couple discovered Christine’s own diagnosis. 

While it hasn’t changed their relationship,  because that’s how it’s always been from the beginning , says McGuinness, he now understands where her behaviour comes from

I think it was really good for Patrick to sit and talk to Paul,  says Christine. 

 When you sit with someone in a similar situation, there’s no judgement.

 That’s what we want with the documentary – not just to raise awareness but for people to understand autism

It follows McGuinness’s own journey to understand his fears around having autistic children, from visiting a school that integrates children with autism into the mainstream, to meeting with footballer Paul Scholes, whose 16-year-old son also has autism

Finding out that Christine too has autism has shone a completely different light on their lives.

A gruesome Beverly Hills murder case is back in the spotlight three decades later, but this time a new generation wants them freed

As I listen to the brothers’ account, what I hear is the sound of two people endlessly trying to explain – to a court, and to the world, but maybe also to themselves – why they did something awful  

Read the full interview with Lyle Menendez here 👇

There are those, of course, who still firmly believe that these were nothing more than two self-centred, evil boys who killed their parents.

Others, believe they are misunderstood victims

However, early in 2020, Court TV posted online footage of the entire months-long first trial, and TikTok became, somewhat unexpectedly, awash with Menendez brothers content

Since then, TikTok videos tagged  have been watched more than 700 million times.

In the short term, this defence was partially successful.

But in 1995 Lyle and Erik were found guilty of murder in the first degree and sentenced to life without possibility of parole

Only in 1993, as their first trial began, was a different narrative presented – one intended to explain both the brothers’ general predicament and the specific lead-up to the actions they took

Each brother described, in great detail, stories of sexual abuse from their own father

That two days before the murders, having learnt that their disappointed father was to disinherit them, the brothers had driven to buy shotguns. 

On that Sunday night, they gunned down their parents, then went out so that they could return home later to feign the discovery

Yet, the following March, two arrests were made, and Lyle and Erik Menendez were charged with murdering their parents.

The predominant story, which would be told over the next 3 years before the case went to trial, was of 2 brothers who were greedy, spoiled, sociopathic brats.

Jose’s sister, Marta, told the press that her brother had been killed because he refused to deal with mobsters.

➡️ After that, the story dropped out of the headlines.

Authorities were presumed to be following up their mob leads

Inevitably, these killings were big news. 

Jose Menendez was a successful executive for a home video company, and even the first Los Angeles Times article reporting the death floated a possible business connection to organised crime

The alarm wasn’t raised until the couple’s two sons, Lyle, 21, and Erik, 18, returned just before midnight to the family home from a nearby movie theatre

Who was the person who was shot?’ the 911 dispatcher asked.

My mom and my dad!’ Lyle sobbed.

On the evening of 20 August 1989, Jose and Kitty Menendez sat down in the living room of their Beverly Hills mansion and watched the James Bond film The Spy Who Loved Me.

They snacked on some blueberries and cream.

And then, at some point that evening, they were brutally killed

❓What is Brexits impact?
 
If the UK was still a member state of the European Union, EU rules would insist migrants be returned to the first safe country in the bloc they landed in.
 
The UK is no longer part of those rules, which makes it more difficult to return migrants

❓Is it a migrant crisis?
 
There are fewer asylum claims and sea crossing in the Channel than other parts of Europe. Asylum claims in the UK have remained stable.
 
More than 416,600 new asylum claims were lodged in European Union member states last year

❓What is the process?
 
Most boats leave the Northern coast of France. This is often the culmination of a long and dangerous journey in the hands of criminal people smugglers.
 
Once in the UK, 98 percent  of the migrants claim asylum, which is a legal right

❓What is France doing?
 
Britain has two recent deals, worth £28mn and £54m with France to pay for increased surveillance of the coast.
 
Since November’s £28m deal, the French have stopped more than 18,000 attempted crossings

🇬🇧Those who do attempt the crossing are likely to speak English rather than French or have family members already in Britain.
 
Others may come from countries with historical ties to Britain or places where the military has been active, such as Afghanistan

❓Why don’t they stay in France? 
 
Many do.
 
Less than 3 percent  of refugees in Europe come to the UK.
 
The mayor of Calais has blamed the British government for not being tough enough on migrants and said the UK had created a pull factor to Britain

❓Why do they want to come to Britain? The reasons are varied.
 
Fleeing persecution for their politics or sexuality.
 
Trying to leave wartorn countries.
 
Economic reasons in the hope of building a better life
25,700 people, more than three times the numbers who made the crossing last year, have attempted to reach Britain by sea, according to the PA

Duncan Wilson, the chief executive of Historic England, said:  To have uncovered such a rare mosaic of this size, as well as a surrounding villa, is remarkable. 
 
Read more on the incredible discovery👇

While further work is needed to properly examine the site, the uniqueness of the literary mosaic has led John Thomas, the dig leader of University of Leicester Archaeological Services, to hail the artwork as  the most exciting Roman mosaic discovery in the UK in the last century

The find was made in the field of Brian Naylor, a Rutland landowner, by his son Jim Irvine, who contacted heritage authorities in 2020.
 
🔎Excavations by University of Leicester revealed significant finds, including human remains likely placed there after the Roman period

⭐️Roman expert, Professor Ken Dark, believes the ostentatious four-panel mosaic was likely  intended to impress guests with how highly educated the owner was .
 
He added:  It is displaying erudition, like quoting one of the classics of English literature at a dinner party

🔙Roman high society held Greek philosophy, literature and language in high regard. The placement of the mosaic in the 3rd or 4th century villa complex is significant, according to Nick Carter, inspector of ancient monuments for Historic England

The 77sq m mosaic would have been a way to flaunt the owner’s erudition to dinner guests, they said.
 
The  rare and remarkable  mosaic has since been protected by the Government on the advice of Historic England

📍The find, located within a 1,700-year-old villa complex in Rutland, is the first mosaic in the UK which depicts scenes from Homers Iliad.
 
Experts have said that the owner of the villa was likely a high-status figure with broad intellectual interests, like  Stephen Fry

🔎Read the full report to find out why Knox labelled the Italian prosecutors version of events a  misogynist fantasy  here 👇
Knox and Sollecito were convicted of murder in 2009; in 2011 their convictions were quashed; in 2013 a new trial was ordered, then in 2015 Italy’s Supreme Court exonerated them for good

The Italian courts could, if they wanted, apologise for the four years she spent in prison and the eight-year legal process in which she was enmeshed, but to do so would be to admit to embarrassing flaws in the country’s legal system
According to Knox,  the controversy, not the truth, is what people care about more , and the reason that controversy lingers on is that the Italian courts have never accepted Guede acted alone
So is it time for us to let go of our fictionalised version of Foxy Knoxy’ and allow married mother Knox to reclaim her life, and her name?
Little wonder, then, that she has called on the newly freed Guede to confess to the crime – which he has always denied, despite DNA evidence – and clear her name once and for all

📰Yet the public fascination with Knox is so intense that it is her name that remains shorthand for the horrific crime, with that of her then-boyfriend Raffaele Sollecito having become hardly more than a footnote

The  man  in that headline was Rudy Guede, an habitual criminal who was convicted of murdering the  roommate , Kercher and who, this week, has been controversially released from jail after serving just 13 years and six months of his 16-year sentence
Knox is so inextricably linked to the events of November 1 2007 that the New York Post ran a headline last year saying:  Man Who Killed Amanda Knox’s Roommate Freed on Community Service

👶Another common one, especially for mothers, is recognition in the wake of a diagnosis of an autistic child.
 
 This seems to have been the case for Sykes – and for quite a few of my autistic friends  writes Limburg

Autistic burnout is the term the autistic community uses to describe that state of utter exhaustion waiting for you at midlife after decades of overthinking, making a conscious effort to fit in, compensation and camouflaging  writes Limburg
The simple answer is that in the 1970s and 1980s, when Sykes and Limburg were both at school, the diagnosis of ASD (autism spectrum disorder) as we now understand it did not exist

🔴More and more women are being diagnosed with autism later in life.
 
 It seems reasonable to ask, why now, and why not before? Where were we all hiding? Why wasn’t Sykes diagnosed at school? Why wasn’t I?  writes Joanne

A woman who is diagnosed in middle age will have half a lifetime of memories of feeling out of place or alone in company. 
 
📅 I remember years at school spent hovering on the edge of groups of girls, not really fitting in or following what was going on  writes Joanne

But the first time we saw each other after lockdown was through plastic in the home’s conservatory.

💬  We can now go to the park, where we sit on our favourite bench and the doves come – there must be 50 or 60 – and feed from our hands

Tony had been aware of his wife’s gradually worsening memory for 17 years before her diagnosis of Alzheimer’s in 2017.

With an  avalanche of support  he had cared for her at home until she was placed in the care of a secure psychiatric unit of a local community hospital

Tony also channelled his creativity into poetry, winning a National Memory Day competition sponsored by Alzheimer’s Society.

Hope you enjoyed the garden tour, more to come as the seasons change. All my love, Tony xxx’

🖋️To try to keep the bond the couple had formed over the course of their 55-year marriage, Tony started to compile beautiful weekly newsletters for Sheila.

They would include family news and document their ever-changing, much loved garden

💬  We had been together for over 50 years. With lockdown the loneliness was terrible. 

 As Sheila no longer talked, we couldn’t chat on the phone, and we didn’t get on with video calls either as they confused her. Sometimes I’d sit and have a good cry

When Tony Ward’s beloved wife, Sheila, moved into a care home in May 2019 he felt grateful that he could visit her every day. Then lockdown happened and those visits stopped.

 I missed Sheila dreadfully,  says Tony

Read @TelegraphBooks the full list of 2021s novels worth adding to the Christmas wish list👇

Great Circle’ - Maggie Shipstead
 
In a year when travelling abroad was tough, Great Circle flew us to a different world.
 
The novel tells two intersecting stories - making clever points about how stories are twisted and provides a rollicking plot

Burntcoat’ - Sarah Hall
 
A Covid-like virus called AG3 turns the world upside-down: once you are infected, there is no chance of survival. Edith, a sculptor, embarks on a risky affair with a Turkish waiter whom she tends to as he fades

A Town Called Solace’ - Mary Lawson
 
A drama about three damaged people living in 1970s Canada, provided old-fashioned narrative pleasures, sharp observation and no little humour

Matrix’ - Laren Groff
 
Set in an English abbey in the 12th century, this pitch-perfect novel follows an unwilling nun called Marie de France (a real poet) who ends up as a power-hungry abbess

No One is Talking About This’ - Patricia Lockwood
 
Written in short paragraphs that could almost be tweets themselves, it begins as very funny satire on our obsession with the internet and social media - before taking a dark turn.

⚡️How to stop overthinking in the middle of the night
🔴Europe faces the return of full lockdowns as the fourth wave of coronavirus brings with it sweeping restrictions - even for the vaccinated
🔎Read the full list of tips from Colin Espie, professor of sleep medicine in the Nuffield Department of Clinical Neurosciences, here 👇

➡️Try to stay awake to fall asleep

During CBT for insomnia, we teach people that trying to remain awake is the key to falling sleep. 

If you wake up at night and don’t immediately fall back to sleep, just lie with your eyes open and keep them open for as long as you can

➡️Reframe sleep positively

The challenge is to change your mindset into that of the good sleeper; to think about sleep and wakefulness in an entirely different and positive way

The good news is that cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT) can fix all these issues. 

Here are some ideas used during a course of CBT that can help 👇
Our mind then goes into overdrive, and inevitably, the harder we try to go back to sleep the more elusive it becomes
😴Just like a child wakes up at night and can either turn back to sleep or wonder where their mum or dad is and wake up properly, we can get into the habit of waking when things are on our mind

🌙Weve all been there – awake at 3am – but while some of us can go back to sleep easily, for others it’s impossible.

War in space is here today.
 
Can the threats be met and reduced? Yes: but it will almost certainly have to be an international effort.
 
Read more⬇️

🌌This is an acknowledgement that, in military terms, space is now seen as a prime combat domain, one worthy of mention in the same breath as land, sea and air.
 
The West has had near-complete unrestricted access to and use of space. But lately the balance has started to shift

The importance of space as a domain has been shown across the globe.
 
🇺🇸In 2019, the president Trump established US Space Command
 
🇫🇷France has renamed its air force as Air and Space Command
 
🇬🇧The UK has created its own version, under RAF tutelage

Space is so vital to militaries that denial of space-based capabilities is an essential task for adversaries.
 
📡Western militaries’ use space for:
Communications
Surveillance
Geo-location
 
And plans for future defence systems are even more wedded to the use of space

⬆️The test was also a major ratcheting-up of at least five years of Russian ASAT tests.
 
Previous attempts had all missed targets – analysts say all the evidence is that these misses were deliberate.
 
By hitting a target Moscow was sending a major signal

News of the event reverberated through the Pentagon and White House, not least because Washington was not given advanced warning.
 
It was only the 4th time a satellite has been taken out by missile from ground - it signalled Moscow can  shoot down  satellites in low earth orbit

🚀The testing of a Russian Anti-Satellite weapon (ASAT) this weekend caused a major stir.
 
With no prior warning, a Russian space weapon was launched and successfully obliterated a defunct Soviet-era spy satellite

📡Satellites will stop working, screens will go blank, military communications will break down.
 
For the person in the street, Google Maps will stop working, and at home, Alexa won’t reply to you.
 
But, actually, war in space is already underway

⚠️If a major superpower war were to erupt – and the drums have recently been beating – then the new Pearl Harbour will not be on a naval or air base (though these will be targeted, too), it will be in space.
 
Russia has fired the first warning

📈More than 520,000 people in Britain have Alzheimer’s disease and the figure is set to rise.

Read the full story 👇
🔴  It opens up the possibility to not only treat Alzheimer’s once symptoms are detected, but also to potentially vaccinate against the disease before symptoms appear,  Professor Carr said
🗣️Professor Carr added:  While the science is currently still at an early stage, if these results were to be replicated in human clinical trials, then it could be transformative

🐁When injected into mice, the vaccine triggered antibodies.

It helped to restore neuron function, increase glucose metabolism in the brain, reverse memory loss and reduce amyloid beta plaque formation
➡️The team theorised that engineering amyloid into the same hairpin shape before administering it as vaccine would spur the body into producing antibodies to fight off that specific structure

Now scientists have discovered that, in people with dementia, the protein folds itself into a hairpin-like structure, and becomes a much more dangerous form of amyloid.

🗣️Professor Mark Carr explained:  This structure had never been seen before in amyloid beta

🔬Previous drugs to fight Alzheimer’s have also concentrated on reducing amyloid.

But they have shown little success in reducing symptoms, with some even triggering negative side effects

💉The vaccine trains the immune system to fight a type of sticky amyloid beta protein in the brain.

It accumulates in people with dementia, preventing communication between neurons

🧠A vaccine against Alzheimer’s disease could be on the horizon after scientists carried out successful trials in animals.

Researchers were able to reverse memory loss in mice and are keen to move quickly to human trials

👥Some people’s brains age faster than others mostly because of environment or lifestyle.

But these good habits can bring life-long benefits to brain health

Read more👇

🥬 Three-quarters of all food in shops comes from 5 animals and 12 plants. Looking further afield is beneficial.

By increasing diversity, we resume the lifestyle of our hunter-gatherer ancestors and increase the chance that we ingest all the nutrients vital to brain health

💞 Frequent sexual intercourse with a close partner can foster better memory, better verbal fluency and even better numeracy skills.

A study on male rats, put together with a receptive female, found that the number of new cells in the male rat’s brain increased massively

The Harvard Adult Development Study found that those who had good-quality relationships were happier, healthier and had better brains in the long-term.

🗨️ Social connections are necessary as food or water

Constantly varying bedtimes, unguarded excesses and irregular habits are also bad for brain health.

💤 Older people still need seven or eight hours of sleep, but you don’t need to do this all in one go. 

Afternoon naps of no more than an hour are to be encouraged

🧠Prolonged daily sitting down is the enemy of brain health. 

Aerobic exercise produces proteins which provoke the release of a protein called BDNF in the brain. 

⚡️This generates new neurones, essentially rejuvenating the brain, a process that takes place until our 90s

🧬 Only 25 percent  of our ageing, both physical, and mental, is determined by our DNA. The other 75 percent  is lifestyle and our environment.

We have a lot of choice over the latter, enabling us to rebuild our brain resilience and mitigate the effects of lockdown 🔻

❌ Loneliness ages us as badly as 15 cigarettes a day, or drinking a bottle of gin, according to a study at University of California, Berkley.

A 12-year Harvard study found that the thinking skills of those who said theyre  lonely  declined 20 percent  more than those who were not

🧠 Prolonged isolation during lockdown had devastating effects on our brain health. 

Social isolation has been robustly proven to hasten dementia and long-term cognitive decline.

Here’s how to reverse pandemic brain ageing 🧵👇

Before I leave, Dr George shows me the tattoo he had done on his wrist

 It was quite painful,  he says.  I was quite brave. 
 
 I don’t doubt him at all.  writes Rosa Silverman
Tonight, he fronts a new BBC Children in Need documentary, Dr Alex: Our Young Mental Health Crisis, which follows the journeys of young people across the UK who are living with mental health issues

He’s also had plenty of experience of dealing with mental ill health in his job, although not everyone realises how often this lies behind what brings people to A&E.
 
 One in three of the people I see, if not more, are here because of mental illness,  he says

I probably had anxiety when I was 15, 16. I’m now 30 and I haven’t really dealt with it until now,  he says.
 
 I [recently] decided to access medication because it’s a hard time. I’m still dealing with grief and also the pressure of this role. It’s not easy

Dr George, who was appointed UK Youth Mental Health Ambassador in February, understands this impulse: the squeamishness that means we send cards when someone dies.
 
But he is a firm believer that talking is vitally important, no matter how difficult the subject

He noticed it almost immediately after his bereavement, which came out of the blue.
 
The day after Llŷr’s death, a friend took him for a walk on the beach in his native Carmarthenshire.
 
 It was like everyone just turned around and walked away and didn’t know what to say

📸After Dr Alex George found fame on Love Island in 2018, strangers would stop him in the street. Yet something changed quite starkly last July, when his younger brother Llŷr took his own life.
 
🗣️ People talk to me a lot less,  says Dr George

📉Another recently-developed antiviral, called Paxlovid, developed by Pfizer, looks even more effective, cutting the risk of hospitalisation and death by 89 percent .

The UK has ordered 250,000 doses of Pfizer’s drug, but it hasn’t yet been approved in the UK

The signs are promising. 

In the US study last year, the drug cut the risk of hospitalisation in half when compared with a placebo

📉Molnupiravir has another advantage: it acts early.

 You simply swallow the capsules when you have the sniffles – and hopefully the sniffles are the worst it gets. 

This would seriously reduce pressure on UK hospitals

Penny Ward, a leading expert in pharmaceutical medicine and visiting professor at King’s College London explains:  

🗣️ It takes too much effort for the virus to change all of its internal proteins regularly.

💊Antivirals target the genetic material in the middle of a virus particle, which generally doesn’t change from mutation to mutation. 

This means they will probably perform well against every variant of Covid
The antiviral drug was approved by the UK medicines regulator last month, bolstering the UK’s reputation as a medical first-mover

In England every year, 400 apprentices take up butchery, but it’s not nearly enough.

🗣️There’s just nobody about to do it, no kids, nothing’ says Preston

Butchers are, on the whole, naturally garrulous, and they’re keen to help

But I find a lot of youngsters come in and feel a bit intimidated, they don’t know what they’re looking for’ says Paul Buttling

As consumers have become more climate-conscious, he’s barely noticed vegans and climatarians denting the business. 

❌It’s nothing compared to the animal rights activists in the ’80s. You’d turn your back for a second and they’d put meat is murder stickers on everything.’

We’ve got some great local support...but people don’t believe me when I tell them 40 percent  of our sales come from tourists,’ Preston says. 

They come in, take a load of pictures, then just buy a jar of jam.’ He laughs; business is business.

What you’ve got to remember about this job,’ Bob Preston says, overseeing a colleague cleave a pig’s leg into bits, is that it’s not very appealing really, is it?’ 

You’re in the cold all day, it’s physical, it’s tiring, you’re starting at 6am, finishing at 6pm

🍖Some say it takes seven years to train to the standard of master butcher’ (not a formal qualification, but understood to mean a butcher able to cut all types of beef, pork, lamb, veal and poultry, as well as train others)

📉Supermarkets, Brexit, the fact our daily meat consumption has dropped 17 percent  in a decade… threats have come from all angles

The trajectory for traditional butchers is grim. 

When you consider that their average age is well over 50 and climbing, it’s even grimmer

🥩 A little over 30 years ago, there were 15,000 independent butcher shops in the UK. 

By 2015, the number had fallen by 60 percent 

Are we witnessing the death of the traditional butcher shop?

The new study is the first to show how omicron compares to previous variants, such as beta and delta, on a level playing field and the preliminary data shows antibodies in blood samples are 41 times less effective for omicron than for the 2020 strain
In reality, the picture is far more complex as human immune systems have other lines of defence that work in tandem with antibodies, such as T-cells

Quite how Covid damages the heart is yet to be fully understood, Dr Raman says. 

 It seems to stem from chronic inflammation, as well as problems with blood flow.

🔬A similar picture is being uncovered by Dr Betty Raman, a British Heart Foundation clinical research fellow.

While her full study is still ongoing, Raman says that in a preliminary assessment of 58 patients,  we are seeing inflammation of multiple organs

🗣️ The heart inflammation fits with a bigger picture of illness,  he explains. 

 We found that quality of life, in terms of physical and mental health, was lower in patients who had heart inflammation. We also saw damage to kidney function in patients who had inflamed hearts.

Research is showing that Covid associated inflammation of the heart muscle (myocarditis) can reduce the heart’s ability to pump and can cause arrhythmias – rapid or irregular heart rhythms – as well as dizziness, chest pain and shortness of breath

Colin Berry, professor of cardiology at the University of Glasgow, is leading one such study. 

📊His team has assessed a random sample of 161 recovering Covid patients, 90 percent  of whom had been hospitalised, and one in five of whom had needed high-level or intensive-care treatment

Aspects of West Side Story feel as pertinent today as they must have done on its 1957 Broadway debut.

 But relevance is easy: timelessness is the real artistic feat. And Spielberg has magnificently pulled it off 

Read more 👇

This is perfect Spielberg: spectacle and sentiment aren’t vying powers here, but complementary forces.

📽️ In a shot of Tony gazing up at Maria’s window, the puddle he’s standing in catches the reflections of nearby neon signs and is transformed into a Technicolor whirlpool

Kushner’s dialogue, meanwhile, has an unobtrusive elegance that lends each conversation an old-fashioned fluency and swish.

💬 The lines aren’t individually showy, but rather conspire to pull the viewer effortlessly along with subtle rhythmic parries and verbal do-si-dos

✍️ Spielberg has made the bold decision not to subtitle any of the Spanish phrases that pepper the script.

 But in doing so, the film refuses to frame the Puerto Ricans as the foreign side: instead, they’re just another ingredient in the great cosmopolitan hotpot

The result is miraculous,  Robbie writes.

📽️ A film which fuses the colour and euphoria of a Golden Age movie musical with the teeming, dirty-fingernailed grandeur of a classic American immigrant epic

🎬 Spielberg and his screenwriter Tony Kushner have stripped down its story of feuding gangs and yearning lovers to its parts...

 ...then rebuilt it with new colour and dynamics drawn from New York social history and Shakespeare’s Romeo and Juliet

✍️ Spielberg has delivered a relentlessly dazzling, swoonily beautiful reworking of the 1957 Manhattan-set musical by Arthur Laurents, Leonard Bernstein and Stephen Sondheim.

 It feels just as definitive and indestructible as the previous screen adaptation

⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️⭐️  West Side Story is, I believe, Spielberg’s finest film in 20 years, and a new milestone in the career of one of our greatest living directors  writes @robbiereviews

🔬And now it is proven they can replicate, they could repair themselves if damaged or torn, scientists hope

💻 After discovering the bots could reproduce, the researchers went back to their computer to design a better shape for reproduction, eventually coming up with an organism resembling Pac-Man, the 1980s arcade game
The process, known as kinematic replication, has been seen in molecular machines but never at higher levels of biology

🧪Now scientists have shown that if the xenobots are placed in a petri dish with embryonic frog stem cells, the bots sweep the cells up into little round piles which morph together into new organisms and also begin to move
🦠The microscopic animal-machine hybrids, dubbed  xenobots  were able to remain  alive  for weeks powered by their embryonic energy stores
🔬In 2020, US researchers programmed a supercomputer to come up with blueprints for entirely new organisms using virtual skin and heart cells, which they then built in real life

⚡️ The weird and wonderful things Queen Elizabeth II owns

Today, like some unwelcome rehash of a movie you didn’t like the first time round, is Mask Day 2. 

Read more

👜 Queen Elizabeth is said to own hundreds of handbags with more than 200 alone being by luxury London designer Launer.

The average price tag for such an accessory is around £1,900

Read the full list 👇

🚘As of 2016, it was estimated that The Queen had a car collection worth £10 million, which included vintage Rolls-Royces and Jaguars.

She is also said to own twin Bentleys that have been built specifically for her

The Queen has owned more than 30 canines in her lifetime including corgis, black Labradors and cocker spaniels.

🐕 In March 2021, she was gifted two new corgi puppies who are now by the monarchs side alongside her corgi-dachshund cross called Candy

🦢The Queen owns all unmarked mute swans in open water in England and Wales – although she only exercises this right on certain stretches of the Thames and its surrounding tributaries.

Every July, a swan census is conducted in a process called  Swan Upping

🖼️One of the worlds largest selections of art, the Royal Collection, contains 150,000 items including Queen Victorias sketchbook, from 1861, and the Crown Jewels.

It belongs to the reigning monarch and it cannot be sold by the king or queen on the throne

🌳Around a quarter of a million acres of rural land across the UK is owned by the Crown Estate. 

Most are leased for the purposes of agriculture and mineral extraction. But around 8 percent  of it is forested, meaning the Queen controls around 95 square miles of British woodland

🛍️The Crown Estate owns almost the entire freehold to Regent Street.

Its central London portfolio also includes almost half of the buildings in St James, where it is currently investing £500 million.

It is Britains fourth-largest owner of directly owned shopping parks

👑Occupying 5 hectares, Windsor is the largest inhabited castle in the world, currently being home to around 150 people.

The castle is used regularly for ceremonial and state occasions and has been home to British monarchy for nearly 1,000 years

➡️Barbados is not the first former imperial colony to achieve independence as a constitutional monarchy and subsequently become a republic.

Yet though she would never query the decision made by Mia Mottley on behalf of the Barbadian people, it seems certain that the nonagenarian monarch will regret the end of her role as Queen of Barbados

With Barbados’s shift to republic status, 14 Commonwealth realms remain, from Australia and Canada to tiny island states like Tuvalu.

⚡️What sleeping less than 6 hours a night does to your brain

Dr Robbins number one rule? 

🕑Set a consistent bedtime.

💉Being sleep deprived can also affect how we respond to vaccines.

 In those people who are vaccinated, we see an increased development of antibodies to combat the viral pathogen - that’s accelerated when you couple vaccine appointments with healthy sleep duration

🦠 How sleep affects our immunity is so relevant right now  says Dr Robbins

 There is one very interesting study that has looked at rhinovirus. The researchers found that those who are sleep-deprived had more than a twofold greater risk of colds and flu
🧠 When we sleep, not only does the brain stop producing these toxins, but it also produces a cerebral fluid which, in essence, pressure-washes the brain to remove the toxins that have built up

📰Fascinating new research published in the journal Science shows just how sleep helps protect the brain.

 We discovered that over the course of the day, the brain produces toxins, the accumulation of which is associated with neuro cognitive decline  says Dr Robbins
